"Provinces and prefectures" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 780; "Hitachi fudoki" at p. 336 It was sometimes called . The province had borders with Iwashiro, Iwaki, Shimōsa, and Shimotsuke Provinces. The ancient capital city of the province was near Ishioka. ==History== In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. The maps of Japan and Hitachi Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Kashima jinjū was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of Hitachi.
